**What makes this different:**
- We'll review your code together, discussing your approach and decisions
- We care about *how* you got to the solution, not just the final result  
- This is a conversation, not a pass/fail exam
- We value clarity, maintainability, and pragmatic problem-solving

**Use this Codefolio to:**
- Document your thought process and key decisions
- Highlight areas you're proud of or want feedback on
- Explain trade-offs you made and why
- Show your communication skills (critical for remote teams!)

**The Challenge:**
zoey-demo-challenge

**What You're Building:**
[The AI agent will fill this in with specific requirements from knowledge.yaml]

**Why This Matters:**
This challenge reflects real work you'd do on our team. We want to see how you approach problems similar to what you'd face day-to-day.

**Time Expectation:**
This should take 2-4 hours for an experienced developer. Quality over speed â€” we'd rather see thoughtful code than rushed features.

**DO:**
âœ… Write code you'd be proud to show your team  
âœ… Include error handling and validation  
âœ… Add comments for complex logic  
âœ… Test your implementation  
âœ… Document your setup and assumptions  
âœ… Ask questions if requirements are unclear (in this Codefolio)  

**DON'T:**
âŒ Just copy-paste from Stack Overflow without understanding  
âŒ Skip error handling to "save time"  
âŒ Leave TODO comments without implementation  
âŒ Over-engineer simple solutions  
âŒ Treat this like a timed exam â€” we want to *talk* about your code!  

**Most Important:**
We're hiring for **collaboration**, not just coding. Show us you can write code that others can understand, maintain, and build upon.

**Using AI Tools? That's Totally Fine! ðŸ¤–**

We know developers use AI assistants like GitHub Copilot, ChatGPT, and others. That's modern software development!

**What We Track (AI-Safeâ„¢):**
- Our system tracks repository activity to ensure code was developed progressively
- We look for natural development patterns (commits, iterations, debugging)
- Red flags: Code that appears all at once with no iteration or debugging

**How to Use AI Responsibly:**
âœ… Use AI for suggestions, boilerplate, and learning  
âœ… Understand and modify the code it generates  
âœ… Work iteratively (commit frequently, refine as you go)  
âœ… Be ready to explain any code in your submission  

âŒ Don't just dump a full AI solution without understanding it  
âŒ Don't skip the development process (we'll see it in git history)  

**Bottom Line:**
AI is a tool. We want to see *your* problem-solving, *your* decisions, and *your* ability to collaborate. Use AI to help you work better, not to skip the work entirely.
